topics.title: File Handling in Python
topics.description: Master reading, writing, and manipulating files in Python

contents.title: Introduction to File Handling
contents.content:
File handling allows you to work with files on your computer - read data, write data, and manipulate files.

Why File Handling:
‚Ä¢ Store data permanently
‚Ä¢ Read configuration files
‚Ä¢ Process large datasets
‚Ä¢ Log application events
‚Ä¢ Import/export data
‚Ä¢ Work with CSV, JSON, text files

File Modes:
‚Ä¢ 'r' - Read (default): Open for reading
‚Ä¢ 'w' - Write: Create new or overwrite
‚Ä¢ 'a' - Append: Add to end of file
‚Ä¢ 'x' - Exclusive: Create new file, fail if exists
‚Ä¢ 'r+' - Read and Write
‚Ä¢ 'b' - Binary mode: For images, videos
‚Ä¢ 't' - Text mode (default)

File Operations:
1. Open file: open()
2. Read/Write: read(), write(), readline()
3. Close file: close()
4. Use with statement (recommended)

Best Practices:
‚Ä¢ Always close files after use
‚Ä¢ Use 'with' statement (auto-closes)
‚Ä¢ Handle exceptions
‚Ä¢ Check if file exists
‚Ä¢ Use appropriate mode
‚Ä¢ Be careful with 'w' mode (overwrites!)

contents.title: Reading Files
contents.content:
# Reading entire file
file = open('example.txt', 'r')
content = file.read()
print(content)
file.close()

# Using with statement (recommended)
with open('example.txt', 'r') as file:
    content = file.read()
    print(content)
# File automatically closed

# Reading line by line
with open('example.txt', 'r') as file:
    for line in file:
        print(line.strip())  # strip() removes \n

# readline() - read one line
with open('example.txt', 'r') as file:
    line1 = file.readline()
    line2 = file.readline()
    print(line1)
    print(line2)

# readlines() - read all lines as list
with open('example.txt', 'r') as file:
    lines = file.readlines()
    print(lines)  # List of lines

# Read specific number of characters
with open('example.txt', 'r') as file:
    first_10 = file.read(10)  # First 10 characters
    print(first_10)

# Check if file exists
import os

if os.path.exists('example.txt'):
    with open('example.txt', 'r') as file:
        content = file.read()
        print(content)
else:
    print('File not found!')

# Handle file not found error
try:
    with open('nonexistent.txt', 'r') as file:
        content = file.read()
except FileNotFoundError:
    print('File does not exist!')
except Exception as e:
    print(f'Error: {e}')

examples.title: Writing to Files
examples.code:
# Write mode ('w') - overwrites file
with open('output.txt', 'w') as file:
    file.write('Hello, World!\n')
    file.write('This is Python file handling.\n')

# Append mode ('a') - adds to end
with open('output.txt', 'a') as file:
    file.write('This line is appended.\n')

# Write multiple lines
lines = [
    'Line 1\n',
    'Line 2\n',
    'Line 3\n'
]

with open('output.txt', 'w') as file:
    file.writelines(lines)

# Write list of items
fruits = ['Apple', 'Banana', 'Mango']

with open('fruits.txt', 'w') as file:
    for fruit in fruits:
        file.write(fruit + '\n')

# Create file if doesn't exist
with open('new_file.txt', 'x') as file:
    file.write('New file created!')

# Copy file content
with open('source.txt', 'r') as source:
    with open('destination.txt', 'w') as dest:
        content = source.read()
        dest.write(content)

# Read and write simultaneously
with open('data.txt', 'r+') as file:
    content = file.read()
    file.write('\nNew line added')
examples.explanation: Use 'w' to create/overwrite files, 'a' to append, 'x' to create new. Always use 'with' statement to ensure files are properly closed.
